channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Price Cap on Russian Oil Wins Backing of G7 Ministers
item.description: The proposal aims to stabilize unsettled energy markets in the wake of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. But it faces considerable obstacles.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: An oil field in Russia. Energy analysts are skeptical that a proposal to corral the price of Russian oil would be successful.

item.title: Against Fierce Resistance, Ukraine Makes Small Gains in the South
item.description: Stepping up an offensive in the region near Kherson, Ukraine has retaken small villages. But officials predict a brutal winter ahead.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier and his fellow tank crew members returning to their frontline position in July after completing a mission in Ukraine’s Kherson region.

item.title: Folders That Had Contained Classified Documents Were Found at Trump’s Home
item.description: A detailed inventory of items seized in the F.B.I.’s search of Mar-a-Lago raised the question of whether the government had fully recovered the documents or any remained missing.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage and Alan Feuer
item.media:description: A more detailed list of the documents that were seized from former President Donald J. Trump’s Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida was unsealed on Friday.

item.title: Trump’s Tastes in Intelligence Were About His Power and Leverage
item.description: President Donald J. Trump’s interests during classified briefings have a new resonance amid the Justice Department’s criminal investigation into his handling of sensitive documents.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Michael C. Bender and Maggie Haberman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Donald J. Trump in the Oval Office. He would sometimes ask to keep material from classified briefings.

item.title: Takeaways From the August Jobs Report
item.description: Hiring slowed last month but remained robust, in line with what many economists had been expecting.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman
item.media:description: The labor force grew by more than three-quarters of a million people last month.

item.title: The Jobs Report Could Be Seen as Good News for Biden
item.description: Slowing job growth and rising worker participation follow the president’s road map for economic transition
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Oliver Contreras for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden at the White House last week.

item.title: Biden Warns That American Values Are Under Assault by Trump-Led Extremism
item.description: In a prime-time speech in Philadelphia, President Biden cast the midterm elections as a choice between his agenda and the extremism of “MAGA Republicans.”
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Oliver Contreras for The New York Times

item.title: They Were at the Capitol on Jan. 6. Now They’re Running for Congress.
item.description: A handful of Republicans who heeded President Donald J. Trump’s call to march to the Capitol are now vying to return to Washington, this time as lawmakers.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Derrick Van Orden, who has won the endorsement of all three top House Republicans, is a favored candidate in Wisconsin.

item.title: On Truth Social, Trump Embraces Far-Right Conspiracy Theories
item.description: The former president’s activity on his social network, Truth Social, openly promotes far-right and conspiratorial ideas that are usually confined to corners of the internet.
item.dc:creator: Stuart A. Thompson
item.media:credit: Emil Lippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: In a 24-hour period, former President Donald J. Trump posted 88 times on Truth Social, amplifying one conspiracy theory after another.

item.title: Trying to Sell Your Old Peloton Bike? So Is Peloton.
item.description: As its business slumps, Peloton is trying something new: selling its bikes to “value-minded” customers. It faces stiff competition.
item.dc:creator: Lora Kelley

item.title: ‘Magic in Her Hands.’ The Woman Bringing India’s Forests Back to Life
item.description: Tulsi Gowind Gowda has spent most of her more than 80 years planting and nurturing trees in southern India. “I like them more than anything else in my life,” she said.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: Priyadarshini Ravichandran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tulsi Gowda has devoted her life to transforming barren land into dense forests in Karnataka, a state in southern India.

item.title: John Podesta to Oversee $370 Billion in U.S. Climate Spending
item.description: Mr. Podesta, a Democratic stalwart, will oversee $370 billion in clean energy investments. Gina McCarthy, the president’s domestic climate adviser, is stepping down.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: John Podesta was a top adviser to President Barack Obama, chief of staff to President Bill Clinton and campaign chairman for Hillary Clinton.

item.title: Venus and Serena William Lose First Round Doubles Match at US Open
item.description: Serena and Venus Williams lost the first set even after having a set point. They eventually were defeated, 7-6 (5), 6-4, by Lucie Hradecka and Linda Noskova of the Czech Republic.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:description: Venus, left, and Serena Williams’s doubles stint lasted only one match.

item.title: Is Andy Murray About to Become Andy Murray Again?
item.description: Like Serena Williams, Andy Murray, finally healthy and fit, has been giving glimpses of yesteryear at the U.S. Open. Unlike Williams, he has no intention of walking away.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman
item.media:description: Andy Murray of Britain after defeating Emilio Nava of the United States in their second-round match at the U.S. Open.

item.title: A Flight Attendant Answers Your Burning Travel and Etiquette Questions
item.description: Where is the best seat if you’re airsick prone? Why don’t flight crews eat the same meals? And the age-old question: Can middle-seat passengers really claim both armrests?
item.dc:creator: Kristie Koerbel
item.media:description: “We all hate the middle,” writes Kristie Koerbel, a flight attendant for 20 years, about the center seat.

item.title: AI-Generated Art Won a Prize. Artists Aren’t Happy.
item.description: “I won, and I didn’t break any rules,” the artwork’s creator says.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose
item.media:description: Jason Allen’s A.I.-generated work, “Théâtre D’opéra Spatial,” took first place in the digital category at the Colorado State Fair.

item.title: If an Alternative Candidate Is Needed in 2024, These Folks Will Be Ready
item.description: If the two parties go off to the edges, there’ll be a ticket running up the center.
item.dc:creator: David Brooks
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times

item.title: The Day Gorbachev Made D.C. Stand Still
item.description: The Adventures of Mikhail Sergeyevich: An astrologer, an anaconda and a backward motorcade.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd
item.media:description: Mikhail Gorbachev in Washington, D.C., after he ordered his motorcade to stop on the way to the White House in 1987.

item.title: Amazon Can’t Fix America’s Health Care Crisis
item.description: There is no technological miracle that will fix decades of bad policy.
item.dc:creator: Libby Watson

item.title: What Brittney Griner’s Income Says About Women’s Basketball
item.description: As her attorneys appeal her conviction in a Russian court, questions remain about why she and other W.N.B.A. stars play abroad to supplement their incomes.
item.dc:creator: Mary Pilon

item.title: Salman Rushdie and What It Means to Support Free Speech
item.description: I felt the power of the rush of readers who ran to the stage when Salman Rushdie was attacked.
item.dc:creator: Henry Reese
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: How to Have Fun Again
item.description: An illustrated guide to letting loose.
item.dc:creator: Wendy MacNaughton

item.title: “The Rings of Power” on Amazon Can’t Do J.R.R. Tolkien Justice
item.description: Amazon’s “The Rings of Power” will struggle to recreate the magic of Middle-earth, a world not fit for “cinematic universe” treatment.
item.dc:creator: Michael D.C. Drout
item.category: The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power (TV Program)
item.media:description: Morfydd Clark in Amazon Studios’ “The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power.” Not all stories are suited to being expanded and exploited by Hollywood.

item.title: The Serena Effect
item.description: An improbable run at what may be her final U.S. Open.
item.dc:creator: Kurt Streeter
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Serena Williams defeated Anett Kontaveit and will face Ajla Tomljanovic in the third round of the U.S. Open on Friday.

item.title: Vancouver’s Unconventional Approach to Its Fentanyl Crisis
item.description: The Canadian city has taken the concept of harm reduction to a new level in an effort to address the growing toxicity of street drugs.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff, Sydney Harper, Jessica Cheung, Asthaa Chaturvedi, M.J. Davis Lin, Liz O. Baylen, Ben Calhoun, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Chelsea Daniel and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Jackie Dives for The New York Times
item.media:description: Injection supplies at a clinic in Vancouver. The fentanyl dispensary at the clinic is legal, and Canada’s public health system finances it.

item.title: Good Things to Make With Summer Corn
item.description: Raw, stir-fried, grilled and puréed — there’s a corn recipe for every mood.
item.dc:creator: Tejal Rao
item.media:credit: Andrew Scrivani for The New York Times

item.title: Why We Get Motion Sick, and How to Stop It
item.description: Experts say prevention is the best cure.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Illustration by Guillem Casasus; Photograph by Getty Images

item.title: Hungry for Cash, Zeldin Turns to Trump in N.Y. Governor’s Race
item.description: Representative Lee Zeldin is depending on Donald J. Trump’s stature to help him in a crucial race for cash, even though Mr. Trump is unpopular in New York.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
item.media:description: For $100,000 a couple, attendees at Representative Lee Zeldin’s fund-raiser this weekend will get time with former President Trump.

item.title: Barbara Ehrenreich, Explorer of Prosperity’s Dark Side, Dies at 81
item.description: Her book “Nickel and Dimed,” an undercover account of the indignities of being a low-wage worker in the United States, is considered a classic in social justice literature.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Schachar
item.category: Nickel and Dimed: On (Not) Getting By in America (Book)
item.media:description: The author Barbara Ehrenreich in 2020. She tackled a variety of themes: the myth of the American dream, the labor market, health care, poverty, women’s rights.

item.title: Kenya Awaits Supreme Court Ruling on Presidential Election
item.description: The Supreme Court is expected to rule by Monday on whether the recent election of William Ruto as president, now mired in a welter of conflicting accusations, should stand.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:description: Kenya's Supreme Court hearing the day's submissions from counsel representing president-elect William Ruto, in Nairobi on Thursday.

item.title: What to Know About the New Covid Booster Shots
item.description: New shots targeting the latest version of the Omicron variant will be available soon. When should you get yours? Here’s what experts recommend.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Charity Rachelle for The New York Times
item.media:description: The new shots target the Omicron subvariant BA.5, the dominant version of the virus.

item.title: The Unexpected Power of Random Acts of Kindness
item.description: New research shows small gestures matter even more than we may think.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson

item.title: How Online Dating Apps Can Lead to Burnout
item.description: Ten years after the launch of Tinder, some long-term online daters say endless swiping has been bad for their mental health.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson

item.title: 5 Foam Rolling Exercises for Skeptics
item.description: Here’s what to know before adding a foam roller to your warm-up or cool down.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Abramson
item.media:credit: Monica Dzik for The New York Times

item.title: Steph Curry’s Graduation From Davidson Was a Long Time Coming
item.description: Curry, the N.B.A. superstar, returned to Davidson College, where he first showed how great he could be. The college, and its community, still feel his impact over a decade later.
item.dc:creator: Anna Katherine Clemmons and Travis Dove
item.media:description: Stephen Curry said going to Davidson College “was kind of the beginning of a major evolution in my life.” It started an evolution for the school, too.
